One of the things I have come across repeatedly in the last few weeks is the argument by creationists (and in some cases ID'ers) that unless human life was created (or designed) by a God, we are all meaningless. One person on UK Radio 2 last week claimed that faith schools do better because children become despondant when taught about evolution....
 
 The topic I'd like to raise is this: Why do creationists / ID'ers believe this? Surely surveying the expanse of evolutionary history and realising just what we have is a very uplifting feeling? Or is it just me? 
 
 I like the idea that of all the flukes that ever happened I was one of them. The fact that this 'random' (Couldn't think of a better word, but I know what Pandion and electrolyte will say :) ) process has lead to a creature able to produce complex culture, languages and art surely shows us just how amazing evolution is.
 
 Anyway, views please!

I was raised as a Roman Catholic and went to a Catholic grade school. In sixth grade, Sister Mary Matthew was teaching us evolution in science class. The conflict with the biblical version of our origins was obvious. I remember asking her about this and I will never forget her response. She asked me to consider the seven days of Genesis. Then she asked me to think about how, out of all of the cosmos, that the earth, and then life and then we came to be, according to scientific theory. She then asked me to decide which I thought was more wonderful. I decided then and there.
 
 Sister Mary Matthew rocked.

So they're saying that if some all-powerful being just created you out of nothing then you're not worthless, yet if your ancestors started out as amoeba and evolved their way up for millions and millions of years then you are worthless?
